summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report of a BOP Material Handler who worked at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The interview, conducted on September 11, 2019, focuses on the officer's duties, standard procedures for counts and rounds, and his specific recollections of the shift on August 9, 2019, the night Jeffrey Epstein died. The officer describes systemic issues with staff exhaustion and cutting corners, and admits to not conducting the 10pm count in the SHU that night.

events.title: Epstein's Last Night in SHU
events.description: Epstein was returned to his cell in the SHU's L-Tier around 8pm, was fed a kosher/commonfare meal 15-20 minutes later, and was left without a cellmate. The 10pm institutional count was not conducted by the officers on duty.

events.title: Suicide Threat in SHU
events.description: At approximately 7:30pm, two inmates in the same cell on L-Tier threatened to hang themselves. Acting Lt. Silvia was called and the inmates were placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell in the SHU at MCC.

events.title: FBI Interview of BOP Officer
events.description: A BOP Material Handler was interviewed by the FBI, OIG, and AUSAs regarding procedures at MCC and the events surrounding Epstein's death.

keyFacts: The BOP officer admitted that the mandatory 10pm institutional count in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) was NOT conducted on the night of August 9, 2019, while Jeffrey Epstein was housed there alone.
The officer stated that Epstein's cellmate had been removed earlier that day, and officers in the SHU should have been notified by the Control Center by 4pm, leaving Epstein alone in his cell.

The officer described systemic problems at MCC, including officers being exhausted, "zombie-like," and routinely cutting corners by falsifying 30-minute round logs due to burnout from excessive mandated overtime.

The officer verified his signature on the 10pm count slip for August 9 but stated he did not assist with the count, meaning Officer Noel would have had to call in a count by herself, which violated the two-officer policy.
The officer had post-death conversations with Officer Noel, who was scared and reluctant to talk, and with another officer who reassured him that Epstein "didn't die on his watch."
